<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 395, 390, 411]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 228, 445]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 870, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 676, 220, 691]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 693, 728, 725]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
The widths, \(w \text{cm}\), of a random sample of 150 leaves of a certain kind were measured. The sample mean of \(w\) was found to be \(3.12 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
Using this sample, an approximate \(95\%\) confidence interval for the population mean of the widths in centimetres was found to be \([3.01, 3.23]\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 176, 146, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 176, 615, 195]]<|/det|>
Calculate an estimate of the population standard deviation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 177, 920, 195]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 820, 186, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 821, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
Explain whether it was necessary to use the Central Limit theorem in your answer to part (a). [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The masses in kilograms of large and small bags of cement have the independent distributions N(50, 2.4) and N(26, 1.8) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total mass of 5 randomly chosen large bags of cement is greater than the total mass of 10 randomly chosen small bags of cement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[69, 83, 84, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 633, 101]]<|/det|>
In this question you should **not** use an approximating distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 920, 164]]<|/det|>
At an election in Menham last year, \(24\%\) of voters supported the Today Party. A student wishes to test whether support for the Today Party has decreased since last year. He chooses a random sample of 25 voters in Menham and finds that exactly 2 of them say that they support the Today Party.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 176, 771, 195]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(5\%\) significance level whether support for the Today Party has decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 177, 918, 195]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 616, 101]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 116, 628, 156]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}ax - x^3 & 0\leqslant x\leqslant \sqrt{2},\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 176, 288, 195]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 208, 146, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 207, 292, 225]]<|/det|>
Show that \(a = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 208, 918, 225]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 700, 185, 719]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 700, 328, 719]]<|/det|>
Find the median of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 700, 917, 719]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 97, 100]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 81, 902, 101]]<|/det|> The numbers of green sweets in 200 randomly chosen packets of Frutos are summarised in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 112, 792, 170]]<|/det|>
Number of green sweets0123> 3
Number of packets325097210
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 183, 146, 201]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 183, 920, 234]]<|/det|> Calculate an unbiased estimate for the population mean of the number of green sweets in a packet of Frutos, and show that an unbiased estimate of the population variance is 0.783 correct to 3 significant figures. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 215, 918, 234]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 740, 845, 761]]<|/det|> The manufacturers of Frutos claim that the mean number of green sweets in a packet is 1.65 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 771, 920, 807]]<|/det|> Anji believes that the true value of the mean, \(\mu\), is less than 1.65 . She uses the results from the 200 randomly chosen packets to test the manufacturers' claim. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 819, 146, 838]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 819, 601, 838]]<|/det|> State suitable null and alternative hypotheses for the test. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 819, 920, 838]]<|/det|> [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 82, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
A sample of 60 randomly chosen pairs of values of \(X\) and \(Y\) is taken, and the value of \(X + Y\) is calculated for each pair. The sample mean of these 60 values is found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 129, 685, 149]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the sample mean of \(X + Y\) is less than 4.0 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 114, 892, 147]]<|/det|>
